016
017package org.parboiled.examples.calculators;
018
019import org.parboiled.Rule;
020import org.parboiled.annotations.BuildParseTree;
021import org.parboiled.examples.calculators.CalculatorParser3.CalcNode;
022import org.parboiled.support.Var;
023import org.parboiled.trees.ImmutableBinaryTreeNode;
024import org.parboiled.support.Var;
025
026/**
027 * A calculator parser building an AST representing the expression structure before performing the actual calculation.
028 * The value field of the parse tree nodes is used for AST nodes.
029 * As opposed to the CalculatorParser2 this parser also supports floating point operations, negative numbers, a "power"
030 * and a "SQRT" operation as well as optional whitespace between the various expressions components.
031 */
032@BuildParseTree
033public class CalculatorParser3 extends CalculatorParser<CalcNode> {
034
035    @Override
036    public Rule InputLine() {
037        return Sequence(Expression(), EOI);
038    }
039
040    Rule Expression() {
041        Var<Character> op = new Var<Character>();
042        return Sequence(
043                Term(),
044                ZeroOrMore(
045                        // we use a FirstOf(String, String) instead of a AnyOf(String) so we can use the
046                        // fromStringLiteral transformation (see below), which automatically consumes trailing whitespace
047                        FirstOf("+ ", "- "), op.set(matchedChar()),
048                        Term(),
049
050                        // same as in CalculatorParser2
051                        push(new CalcNode(op.get(), pop(1), pop()))
052                )
053        );
054    }
055
056    Rule Term() {
057        Var<Character> op = new Var<Character>();
058        return Sequence(
059                Factor(),
060                ZeroOrMore(
061                        FirstOf("* ", "/ "), op.set(matchedChar()),
062                        Factor(),
063                        push(new CalcNode(op.get(), pop(1), pop()))
064                )
065        );
066    }
067
068    Rule Factor() {
069        return Sequence(
070                Atom(),
071                ZeroOrMore(
072                        "^ ",
073                        Atom(),
074                        push(new CalcNode('^', pop(1), pop()))
075                )
076        );
077    }
078
079    Rule Atom() {
080        return FirstOf(Number(), SquareRoot(), Parens());
081    }
082
083    Rule SquareRoot() {
084        return Sequence(
085                "SQRT ",
086                Parens(),
087
088                // create a new AST node with a special operator 'R' and only one child
089                push(new CalcNode('R', pop(), null))
090        );
091    }
092
093    Rule Parens() {
094        return Sequence("( ", Expression(), ") ");
095    }
096
097    Rule Number() {
098        return Sequence(
099                // we use another Sequence in the "Number" Sequence so we can easily access the input text matched
100                // by the three enclosed rules with "match()" or "matchOrDefault()"
101                Sequence(
102                        Optional('-'),
103                        OneOrMore(Digit()),
104                        Optional('.', OneOrMore(Digit()))
105                ),
106
107                // the matchOrDefault() call returns the matched input text of the immediately preceding rule
108                // or a default string (in this case if it is run during error recovery (resynchronization))
109                push(new CalcNode(Double.parseDouble(matchOrDefault("0")))),
110                WhiteSpace()
111        );
112    }
113
114    Rule Digit() {
115        return CharRange('0', '9');
116    }
117
118    Rule WhiteSpace() {
119        return ZeroOrMore(AnyOf(" \t\f"));
120    }
121
122    // we redefine the rule creation for string literals to automatically match trailing whitespace if the string
123    // literal ends with a space character, this way we don't have to insert extra whitespace() rules after each
124    // character or string literal
125
126    @Override
127    protected Rule fromStringLiteral(String string) {
128        return string.endsWith(" ") ?
129                Sequence(String(string.substring(0, string.length() - 1)), WhiteSpace()) :
130                String(string);
131    }
132
133    //****************************************************************
134
135    /**
136     * The AST node for the calculators. The type of the node is carried as a Character that can either contain
137     * an operator char or be null. In the latter case the AST node is a leaf directly containing a value.
138     */
139    public static class CalcNode extends ImmutableBinaryTreeNode<CalcNode> {
140        private double value;
141        private Character operator;
142
143        public CalcNode(double value) {
144            super(null, null);
145            this.value = value;
146        }
147
148        public CalcNode(Character operator, CalcNode left, CalcNode right) {
149            super(left, right);
150            this.operator = operator;
151        }
152
153        public double getValue() {
154            if (operator == null) return value;
155            switch (operator) {
156                case '+':
157                    return left().getValue() + right().getValue();
158                case '-':
159                    return left().getValue() - right().getValue();
160                case '*':
161                    return left().getValue() * right().getValue();
162                case '/':
163                    return left().getValue() / right().getValue();
164                case '^':
165                    return Math.pow(left().getValue(), right().getValue());
166                case 'R':
167                    return Math.sqrt(left().getValue());
168                default:
169                    throw new IllegalStateException();
170            }
171        }
172
173        @Override
174        public String toString() {
175            return (operator == null ? "Value " + value : "Operator '" + operator + '\'') + " | " + getValue();
176        }
177    }
178
179    //**************** MAIN ****************
180
181    public static void main(String[] args) {
182        main(CalculatorParser3.class);
183    }
184}
